{{distinguish2|XXY (2 X's, [[Klinefelter's syndrome]])}} {{Infobox Disease | Image = Chromosome Y.svg | Caption = [[Y chromosome|Y-chromosome]] | DiseasesDB = 33038 | ICD10 = {{ICD10|Q|98|5|q|90}} | ICD9 = {{ICD9|758.8}} | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | MeshID = D014997 }} '''XYY syndrome''' is an [[aneuploidy]] (abnormal number) of the [[sex chromosome]]s in which a [[human]] [[male]] receives an extra [[Y chromosome|Y-chromosome]], giving a total of 47 chromosomes instead of the more usual 46. This produces a '''47,XYY''' [[karyotype]]. This condition is usually asymptomatic and affects 1 in 1000 male births.
Some medical geneticists question whether the term "[[syndrome]]" is appropriate for this condition because its [[phenotype]] is normal{{contradiction-inline|date=December 2011|reason=Below, it is stated to result in lowered IQs (and greater heights)}} and the vast majority (an estimated 97% in the UK) of 47,XYY males do not know their [[karyotype]].<ref name=allanson>{{cite book |author=Graham, Gail E.; Allanson, Judith E.; Gerritsen, Jennifer A. |year=2007 |chapter=Sex chromosome abnormalities |editor=Rimoin, David L.; Connor, J. Michael.; Pyeritz, Reed E.; Korf, Bruce R. ==Physical traits== Most often, the extra Y-chromosome causes no unusual physical features or medical problems. Since XYY is not characterized by distinct physical features, the condition is usually detected only during genetic analysis for another reason.
47,XYY boys have an increased growth velocity during earliest childhood, with an average final height approximately 7 cm (3 in) above expected final height.<ref name=nielsen>{{cite web |author=Nielsen, Johannes |year=1998 |title=How is height growth? |url=http://www.aaa.dk/TURNER/ENGELSK/XYY.HTM#height |work=XYY males. An orientation |publisher=The Turner Center, [[Aarhus]] Psychiatric Hospital, [[Risskov]], [[Denmark]] |accessdate=2008-01-11}}</ref> The increased gene dosage of three X/Y chromosome [[pseudoautosomal region]] (PAR1) [[short stature homeobox gene|SHOX]] genes has been postulated as a cause of the increased stature seen in all three sex chromosome trisomies: 47,XXX, 47,XXY, and 47,XYY.<ref name="SHOX">{{cite book |author=Cohen, Pinchas; Shim, Melanie |year=2007 |chapter=Hyperpituitarism, tall stature, and overgrowth syndromes |editor=Kliegman, Robert M.; Behrman, Richard E.; Jenson, Hal B.; Stanton, Bonita F. (eds.) |title=Nelson textbook of pediatrics |edition=18th |location=Philadelphia |publisher=[[Elsevier|Saunders]] |isbn=1416024506 |pages=2303â2307}} p. 2304: Table 561-1. Differential diagnosis of tall stature and overgrowth syndromes. Postnatal overgrowth leading to childhood tall statureâincludes: Klinefelter syndrome (XXY), SHOX excess syndromes, XYY. * {{cite journal |author=Kanaka-Gantenbein, Christina; Kitsiou, Sophia; Mavrou, Ariadni; Stamoyannou, Lela; Kolialexi, Aggeliki; Kekou, Kyriaki; Liakopoulou, Magda; Chrousos, George |date=April 2004 |title=Tall stature, insulin resistance, and disturbed behavior in a girl with the triple X syndrome harboring three SHOX genes: offspring of a father with mosaic Klinefelter syndrome but with two maternal X chromosomes |journal=[[Hormone Research (journal)|Horm Res]] |volume=61 |issue=5 |pages=205â210 |doi=10.1159/000076532 |pmid=14752208}} * {{cite journal |author=Aksglaede, Lise; Skakkebaek, Niels E.; Juul, Anders |date=January 2008 |title=Abnormal sex chromosome constitution and longitudinal growth: serum levels of insulin-like growth factor (IGF)-I, IGF binding protein-3, luteinizing hormone, and testosterone in 109 males with 47,XXY, 47,XYY, or sex-determining region of the Y chromosome (SRY)-positive 46,XX karyotypes |journal=[[Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism|J Clin Endocrinol Metab]] |volume=93 |issue=1 |pages=169â176 |doi=10.1210/jc.2007-1426 |pmid=17940117 |url=http://jcem.endojournals.org/cgi/reprint/93/1/169.pdf}} * {{cite journal |author=TÃ¼ttelmann, Frank; Gromoll, JÃ¶rg |year=2010 |title=Novel genetic aspects of Klinefelter's syndrome |journal=Mol Hum Reprod |volume= 16|issue= 6|pages= 386â95|doi=10.1093/molehr/gaq019 |pmid=20228051}}</ref>
Severe [[Acne vulgaris|acne]] was noted in a very few early case reports, but dermatologists specializing in acne now doubt the existence of a relationship with 47,XYY.<ref name=plewig>{{cite book |author=Plewig, Gerd; Kligman, Albert M. |year=2000 |title=Acne and rosacea |edition=3rd |page=377 |location=Philadelphia |publisher=[[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer-Verlag]] |isbn=3540667512}}</ref>

As with [[Klinefelter's syndrome|47,XXY]] boys<ref name="GTPBP6">The increased gene dosage of three pseudoautosomal region PAR1 [[GTPBP6]] genes in Klinefelter's syndrome (47,XYY) has been correlated with decreased verbal IQ. * {{cite journal |author=Fernando Gianfrancesco, Fernando; et al. |date=March 1998 |title=A novel pseudoautosomal gene encoding a putative GTP-binding protein resides in the vicinity of the Xp/Yp telomere |journal=[[Human Molecular Genetics|Hum Mol Genet]] |volume=7 |issue=3 |pages=407â414|doi=10.1093/hmg/7.3.407 |pmid=9466997 |url=http://hmg.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/reprint/7/3/407.pdf}} * {{cite journal |author=Vawter, Marquis P.; Harvey, Philip D.; DeLisi, Lynn E. |date=September 5, 2007 |title=Dysregulation of X-Linked Gene Expression in Klinefelter's Syndrome and Association With Verbal Cognition |journal=[[American Journal of Medical Genetics|Am J Med Genet B Neuropsychiatr Genet]] |volume=144B |issue=6 |pages=728â734 |doi=10.1002/ajmg.b.30454 |pmid=17347996 |pmc=2094046 }}</ref> and [[Triple X syndrome|47,XXX]] girls, [[IQ]] scores of 47,XYY boys average 10â15 points below their siblings.<ref name=guys/><ref name=linden2002a/><ref name="Milunsky 2010"/><ref name=firth/><ref name=nussbaum/> For context, this amount of variationâan average difference of 12 IQ pointsâoften occurs naturally between children in the same family,<ref name=guys/><ref name=scarr>{{cite book |author=Scarr, Sandra; Deater-Deckard, Kirby |year=1997 |chapter=Family effects on individual differences in development |editor=Luthar, Suniya S. The Denver Family Development Study led by Arthur Robinson<ref name="robinson a">{{cite journal |author=Robinson, Arthur |month=April |year=1990 |title=Living history: an autobiography of Arthur Robinson |journal=[[American Journal of Medical Genetics|Am J Med Genet]] |volume=35 |issue=4 |pages=475â480 |doi=10.1002/ajmg.1320350406 |pmid=2185631}}</ref> found that in 14 [[prenatal diagnosis|prenatally diagnosed]] 47,XYY boys (from high [[socioeconomic status]] families), IQ scores available for 6 boys ranged from 100â147 with a mean of 120.<ref name=linden2002b>{{cite journal |author=Linden, Mary G.; Bender, Bruce G. |date=June 1, 2002 |title=Fifty-one prenatally diagnosed children and adolescents with sex chromosome abnormalities |journal=[[American Journal of Medical Genetics|Am J Med Genet]] |volume=110 |issue=1 |pages=11â18 |pmid=12116265 |doi=10.1002/ajmg.10394}}</ref> For the 11 of 14 boys with siblings, in 9 instances their siblings were stronger academically, but in one case the subject was performing equal to, and in another case superior to, his siblings.<ref name=linden2002b/>
Developmental delays and behavioral problems are also possible, but these characteristics vary widely among affected boys and men, are not unique to 47,XYY and are managed no differently than in 46,XY males.<ref name=linden2002a/><ref name="Milunsky 2010"/><ref name=ghr/> Aggression is not seen more frequently in 47,XYY males.<ref name=allanson/><ref name=guys/><ref name=linden2002a/><ref name="Milunsky 2010"/><ref name=beltz/><ref name=nussbaum/>
==Cause== [[File:XYY syndrome.svg|thumb|right]]47,XYY is not inherited, but usually occurs as a random event during the formation of [[Spermatozoon|sperm]] cells. An error in chromosome separation during anaphase II (of [[meiosis#Meiosis II|meiosis II]]) called [[nondisjunction]] can result in sperm cells with an extra copy of the Y-chromosome. If one of these atypical sperm cells contributes to the genetic makeup of a child, the child will have an extra Y-chromosome in each of the body's cells.<ref name=ghr/><ref name="robinson do">{{cite journal |author=Robinson, David O.; Jacobs, Patricia A. |date=November 1, 1999 |title=The origin of the extra Y chromosome in males with a 47,XYY karyotype |journal=[[Human Molecular Genetics|Hum Mol Genet]] |volume=8 |issue=12 |pages=2205â2209 |pmid=10545600 |url=http://hmg.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/reprint/8/12/2205.pdf |doi=10.1093/hmg/8.12.2205}}</ref>
In some cases, the addition of an extra Y-chromosome results from nondisjunction during cell division during a post-zygotic [[mitosis]] in early embryonic development. This can produce 46,XY/47,XYY [[Mosaic (genetics)|mosaic]]s.<ref name=ghr/><ref name="robinson do"/>
==Incidence== About 1 in 1,000 boys are born with a 47,XYY karyotype.<ref name=allanson/><ref name="Milunsky 2010"/><ref name=firth/> The incidence of 47,XYY is not affected by advanced paternal or maternal age.<ref name=allanson/><ref name="Milunsky 2010"/><ref name=firth/>
==History== ===1960s=== In April 1956, ''[[Hereditas]]'' published the discovery by [[cytogenetics|cytogeneticist]]s [[Joe Hin Tjio]] and [[Albert Levan]] at [[Lund University]] in [[Sweden]] that the normal number of chromosomes in [[ploidy|diploid]] human cells was 46ânot 48 as had been believed for the preceding thirty years.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1601-5223.1956.tb03010.x |author=Tjio, Joe Hin; Levan, Albert |date=April 1956 |title=The chromosome number of man |journal=[[Hereditas]] |volume=42 |issue=1 |pages=1â6}}</ref> In the wake of the establishment of the normal number of human chromosomes, 47,XYY was the last of the common sex chromosome aneuploidies to be discovered, two years after the discoveries of [[Klinefelter's syndrome#Cause|47,XXY]],<ref>{{cite journal |author=Jacobs, Patricia A.; Strong, John A. |date=January 31, 1959 |title=A case of human intersexuality having a possible XXY sex-determining mechanism |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |volume=183 |issue=4657 |pages=302â3 |doi= 10.1038/183302a0 |pmid=13632697}}</ref> [[Turner syndrome#History|45,X]],<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ford, Charles E.; Jones, Kenneth W.; Polani, Paul E.; de Almeida, JosÃ© Carlos Cabral; Briggs, John H. |date=April 4, 1959 |title=A sex-chromosome anomaly in a case of gonadal dysgenesis (Turner's syndrome) |journal=[[The Lancet|Lancet]] |volume=273 |issue=7075 |pages=711â3 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(59)91893-8 |pmid=13642858}}</ref> and [[Triple X syndrome#First_case|47,XXX]]<ref>{{cite journal |author=Jacobs, Patricia A.; Baikie, Albert G.; Court Brown, W. Michael; MacGregor, Thomas N.; Harnden, David G. |date=September 26, 1959 |title=Evidence for the existence of the human "super female" |journal=[[The Lancet|Lancet]] |volume=274 |issue=7100 |pages=423â5 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(59)90415-5 |pmid=14406377}}</ref> in 1959. Even the much less common [[48,XXYY syndrome|48,XXYY]]<ref>{{cite journal |author=Muldal, Sylfest; Ockey, Charles, H. |date=August 27, 1960 |title=The "double male": a new chromosome constitution in Klinefelter's syndrome |journal=[[The Lancet|Lancet]] |volume=276 |issue=7147 |pages=492â3 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(60)91624-X}}</ref> had been discovered in 1960, a year before 47,XYY.
Screening for those [[X chromosome]] aneuploidies was possible by noting the presence or absence of "female" sex chromatin bodies ([[Barr body|Barr bodies]]) in the [[cell nucleus|nuclei]] of [[interphase]] cells in [[Buccal smear#Medical procedure|buccal smear]]s, a technique developed a decade ''before'' the first reported sex chromosome aneuploidy.<!-- --><ref name="barr 1949">{{cite journal |author=Barr, Murray, L.; Bertram, Ewart G. |date=April 30, 1949 |title=A morphological distinction between neurones of the male and female, and the behaviour of the nucleolar satellite during accelerated nucleoprotein synthesis |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |volume=163 |issue=4148 |pages=676â677 |doi=10.1038/163676a0 |pmid=18120749 |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v163/n4148/pdf/163676a0.pdf |format=}} {{dead link|date=July 2010}}</ref> An analogous technique to screen for Y-chromosome aneuploidies by noting supernumerary "male" sex chromatin bodies was not developed until 1970, a decade ''after'' the first reported sex chromosome aneuploidy.<!-- --><ref name="pursuit 1970">{{cite journal |author=. |date=June 6, 1970 |title=In pursuit of the ''Y'' chromosome |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |volume=226 |issue=5249 |pages=897 |doi=10.1038/226897a0 |pmid=4192294}} * {{cite journal |author=. |date=February 6, 1971 |title=Dyeing the ''Y'' chromosome |journal=[[The Lancet|Lancet]] |volume=297 |issue=7693 |pages=275â276 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(71)91008-7}}</ref>

In 1973, child psychiatrist Herbert Schreier at Childrenâs Hospital told Harvard Medical School microbiologist [[Jon Beckwith]] of [[Science for the People]] that he thought Walzerâs Boston XYY study was unethical; Science for the People investigated the study and filed a complaint with Harvard Medical School about the study in March 1974.<ref name="Beckwith 2002"/> The Harvard Medical committee on medical research recommended that the study continue, as did the entire faculty when the issue was brought before them for a vote.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=pMz_of-L4lYC&lpg=PA224&ots=giYAez5f_O&dq=%2B%22Science%20for%20the%20People%22%20%2BXYY&pg=PA224#v=onepage&q=+%22Science%20for%20the%20People%22%20+XYY&f=false|title=Science as a process: an evolutionary account of the social and conceptual development of science|first=David|last=Hull|year=1990|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=0-226-36051-2}}</ref> In November 1974, Science for the People went public with their objections to the Boston XYY study in a press conference and a ''[[New Scientist]]'' article alleging inadequate informed consent, a lack of benefit (since no specific treatment was available) but substantial risk (by stigmatization with a false stereotype) to the subjects, and that the unblinded experimental design could not produce meaningful results regarding the subjects' behavior.<ref name="Beckwith 2002"/><ref name="Boston"/> Changes to informed consent procedures and pressure from additional advocacy groups, including the [[Children's Defense Fund]], led to the 1975 discontinuation of the last active U.S. newborn screening programs for sex chromosome abnormalities in Boston and Denver.<ref name="Beckwith 2002"/><ref name="Boston"/>{{Verify credibility|date=December 2011|reason=Second portion of sentence may well be factual; dubious about first}}
In August 1976, ''Science'' published a [[retrospective cohort study]] by [[Educational Testing Service]] psychologist Herman Witkin and colleagues that screened the tallest 16% of men (over 6'0" in height) born in [[Copenhagen]] from 1944â1947 for XXY and XYY karyotypes, and found an increased rate of minor criminal convictions for property crimes among sixteen XXY and twelve XYY men may be related to the lower intelligence of those with criminal convictions, but found no evidence that XXY or XYY men were inclined to be aggressive or violent.<ref name="Witkin 1976">{{cite journal |author=Witkin, Herman A.; et al. |date=August 13, 1976 |title=Criminality in XYY and XXY men |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |volume=193 |issue=4253 |pages=547â555 |doi=10.1126/science.959813 |pmid=959813 }} * {{cite news |author=Brody, Jane E. |date=September 12, 1976 |title=A chromosome link to crime is doubted; Study in Denmark finds no data to back view that 'XYY' men are inclined to be violent |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |page=18 |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0F12FE3F5E1A7493C0A81782D85F428785F9}}</ref>
===1980s and later=== The [[March of Dimes]] sponsored five international conferences in June 1974, November 1977, May 1981, June 1984, and June 1989 and published articles from the conferences in book form in 1979, 1982, 1986, and 1991 from seven longitudinal prospective studies on the development of over 300 children and young adults with sex chromosome abnormalities identified in the screening of almost 200,000 consecutive births in hospitals in Denver, Edinburgh, New Haven, Toronto, Aarhus, Winnipeg, and Boston from 1964 to 1975.<ref name="March of Dimes"/><ref>The five March of Dimes international conferences and four books also included reports on the findings of longitudinal prospective studies in [[London, Ontario]] and [[Tokyo]] on the development of children and with sex chromosome abnormalities identified in part by newborn screening programs.</ref> These seven studiesâthe only unbiased studies of unselected individuals with sex chromosome abnormalitiesâhave replaced the older, biased studies of institutionalized individuals in understanding the development of individuals with sex chromosome abnormalities.<ref name="Milunsky 2010"/><ref>The last active longitudinal prospective study ended in 2000 with the end of the 36-year Denver study following the death of pediatrician and geneticist Arthur Robinson. * {{cite book |author=Robinson, Arthur; Linden, Mary G.; Bender, Bruce G. |year=1998 |chapter=Prenatal diagnosis of sex chromosome abnormalities |pages=249â285 |editor=Milunsky, Aubrey (ed.) |title=Genetic disorders and the fetus : diagnosis, prevention and treatment |edition=4th |location=Baltimore |publisher=[[Johns Hopkins University Press]] |isbn=0801858011}} * {{cite journal |month=May/June |year=2001 |title=Life adaptation in 35 adults with sex chromosome abnormalities |journal=Genet Med |volume=3 |issue=3 |pages=187â191 |pmid=11388759 |author=Bender, Bruce G.; Linden, Mary G.; Harmon, Robert J. |doi=10.1097/00125817-200105000-00007}}</ref>
In May 1997, ''[[Nature Genetics]]'' published the discovery by Ercole Rao and colleagues of the X/Y chromosome [[pseudoautosomal region]] (PAR1) [[short stature homeobox gene|SHOX]] gene, [[haploinsufficiency]] of which leads to short stature in [[Turner syndrome]] (45,X).<ref name="Rao"> {{cite journal |author=Rao, Ercole; et al. |date=May 1997 |title=Pseudoautosomal deletions encompassing a novel homeobox gene cause growth failure in idiopathic short stature and Turner syndrome |journal=[[Nature Genetics|Nat Genet]] |volume=16 |issue=1 |pages=54â63 |doi=10.1038/ng0597-54 |pmid=9140395}}</ref> It was subsequently postulated that the increased gene dosage of three SHOX genes leads to tall stature in the sex chromosome trisomies 47,XXX, 47,XXY, and 47,XYY.<ref name="SHOX"/> In September 2007, the ''[[American Journal of Medical Genetics]]'' published a report by Marquis Vawter and colleagues that the increased gene dosage of three pseudoautosomal region PAR1 [[GTPBP6]] genes in Klinefelter's syndrome (47,XXY) was correlated with decreased verbal IQ.<ref name="GTPBP6"/>
